Introduction - How to Learn What You Don‚Äôt Know Without A Teacher
Learning how to learn is the fundamental skill of learning. It implies we must know about ourselves, our abilities, and our limits and understand the knowledge landscape. It‚Äôs been our experience that most people fail to achieve good results with LLMs because they approach them expecting answers, instead of approaching them to produce answers themselves, aided by the tool.  To use LLMs effectively we must understand them deeply, understand learning deeply, and to map between learning needs and the architecture and mechanics LLMs have that open up different affordances. 

Intuitively we can do this through a simplified geometric representation of a goal and a knowledge map and some intuitive leaps. We are approaching this practically and comprehensively, although when fudging between technical accuracy and usefulness comes, we will err on the side of useful. It is our hope to refine this approach further till there comes a day we do not have to make any logical compromises.  

We believe it may be possible to have  a one to one map for the production of data points, which leads to information, which is then refined into knowledge both within the human mind as a learner, as well as within leverageable structures within LLMs. The question of wisdom will likely remain the domain of the human, and this is the essence of our hypothesis. 
Why does this matter? The automation process continues to reduce work that was meaningful because only a human could do it, once a machine is able to do work, the essence of where we draw meaning from is reduced. So, what is a human for im an age of LLMs and AI? I believe it is our job to access our zone of genius, that place where your unique voice will make a true contribution not present in the embedding space. And I believe that by appropriate LLM use we can develop just in time expertise by learning the gap between where we are and our goals, identify the prior knowledge, map the landscape of a problem space, and identify and address your unknown unknowns till you arrive at your destination. 


To get the intuition we will be exploring the idea of vector spaces and goals geometrically and together we‚Äôll be traveling through vector spaces. Once you grasp this idea, you'll be able to learn things that you didn't even know you needed to learn. And then, you will be able to perform tasks you didn't know you needed to do.

Since last December, we've built this intuition after hundreds of hours of GPT use. Now, we‚Äôre sharing it with a series of practical methods to support others in getting better results while developing their deep understanding of what‚Äôs special about LLMs and how to get good results. This is how you learn prompting.

We call this LLM framework and techniques S.C.R.I.B.E.R (Seek, Critique, Reflect, Inquire, Broaden/contract, Explain, Recurse), and we can teach you and your team how to get excellent results from LLMs while building their capacity and identifying their unique contributions.

The S.C.R.I.B.E.R Framework for Prompting
‚óè  	Seek: Exploring your gaps in different domains of knowledge.
‚óè  	Critique: Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist personas.
‚óè  	Reflect: Procedurally review the LLM‚Äôs work and create tools with which to think.
‚óè  	Inquire: Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new spaces.
‚óè  	Broaden/Contract: Seek gaps, ask the LLM for non-overlapping options, and pick.
‚óè  	Explain: Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and corrections.
‚óè  	Recurse: Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you.
 
The following table shares the SCRIBE Framework in three parts.
 
Principles are ideas you keep in mind and attempt to act upon them.
Techniques are how you can apply the principles. It‚Äôs just one method of many.
The Way of Being is a quality of presence from which principles and techniques can emerge. It can be cultivated by repeated practice of the techniques and deep reflection on the principles. It is what matters in the end.
  
Note: Do not memorize this list.
These techniques and principles are tools to help us embody the knowledge. Aim to have a mindset of using LLMs as a tool for thought.
The ultimate goal of learning is to become.

Work Rant: As LLMs arrive and further increase the diversity of automatable work, and as 450M people might need to identify new roles and jobs, the question of what is a human life for becomes ever more urgent. Prior to the invention of labor saving machines human effort and competency was valued more and workers made a living wage in work they could find meaning in. Once it became possible to see workers and laborers as redundant artifacts from the past, labor became less valued and the self image of laborers in factories was damaged. This similar process will happen in knowledge work. An industrial labor process is not a craft. It might be possible that a craft is still worth doing and that people love a handmade notebook. Yet the efficiency of processes is a seductive process which is impossible to avoid. Why wouldn‚Äôt we make things easier when the job doesn‚Äôt provide meaning, the artistry is lacking, each piece is assessed on it‚Äôs consistency with the initial mold making creativity useless. We love hand made things when it touches the soul of a craftsperson, when creativity can emerge, when uniqueness is transferred. Knowledge workers will have to contend with questions very similar. Why would I hire you to write copy when I can have an AI AB test day and night and emulate the best writers that I love the most? Or data entry? Done. No one wants that job, it‚Äôs just a job that needed to exist for a while and people took it who didn‚Äôt have enough knowledge or education to do otherwise, or all other jobs in their area were taken.
